sen.j: 茶屋辻（ちゃやつじ）は和服の文様の一種。
sen.e: Chayatsuji is a pattern for wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).
Chayatsuji is a pattern for wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).
Chayatsuji is a pattern for wafuku (Japanese traditional clothes).

sen.j: 水辺の風景を細かい文様で著した物を指し、基本的に夏の着物に適用される。
sen.e: The fine pattern illustrates the scenery of the waterside, and it is fundamentally applied to summer kimono.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The Chayatsuji is characterized by its fine pattern which illustrates waterside scenery, and it is fundamentally applied to summer kimono.
The Chayatsuji is characterized by its fine pattern which illustrates waterside scenery, and it is fundamentally applied to summer kimono.

sen.j: しかし、近年は例外も多い。
sen.e: However, there are also many exceptions in recent years.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: However, there are also many exceptions in recent years.
However, there are also many exceptions in recent years.

sen.j: 「辻」とは「帷子」（麻単の着物）のことであり、つまり「”茶屋”の帷子」というのが本意である。
sen.e: Tuji refers "Katabira" (light hemp kimono); in another words, it means "Katabira of 'chaya'."
The term "Tsuji" here refers to "Katabira" (an unlined lightweight hemp summer kimono), and more accurately, it means a "Katabira in the 'chaya' pattern."
The term 'Tsuji' here refers to 'Katabira' (an unlined lightweight hemp summer kimono), and more accurately, it means a 'Katabira in the "chaya" pattern.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 「茶屋」とは「茶屋染」という江戸時代の初期（寛文年間）頃に発明された染色の一種を指す。
sen.e: The "chaya" refers to a dye technique invented at the early-days of the Edo period called "chayazome."
The term "Chaya" refers to a dye technique called "Chaya-zome" (Chaya-dyed) invented in the early Edo period (Kanbun era).
The term 'Chaya' refers to a dye technique called 'Chaya-zome' (Chaya-dyed) invented in the early Edo period (Kanbun era).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション調整

sen.j: 本来は麻にしか染められなかった模様。
sen.e: The pattern was originally dyed only on hemp.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The pattern was originally dyed only on hemp.
The pattern was originally dyed only on hemp.

sen.j: だが、現在は麻の礼服自体が珍しく、もっぱら絹（絽や紗といった薄手の物）に染められることが多い。
sen.e: However, hempen full dress is rare nowadays, and it is often dyed on silk (thin silk, such as silk gauze).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: However, hemp full dresses themselves are rare nowadays, and the Chaya-zome is mostly done on silk (thin silk, such as silk gauze, including Ro and Sha fabrics in Japanese).
However, hemp full dresses themselves are rare nowadays, and the Chaya-zome is mostly done on silk (thin silk, such as silk gauze, including Ro and Sha fabrics in Japanese).

sen.j: また、格式の高さから合い物・冬物に使われることすらある。
sen.e: Moreover, it is sometimes used even for spring, fall and winter clothes because of its high formality.
Moreover, it is sometimes used even for spring, fall and winter clothes because of its high formality.
Moreover, it is sometimes used even for spring, fall and winter clothes because of its high formality.

sen.j: この「茶屋」の語源については、茶屋四郎次郎が染め方や図案を考えたことから、というのが定説である。
sen.e: The established theory is that it is called "chaya" because Shirojiro CHAYA created dye technique and a design.
The established theory is that it is called "Chaya" because Shirojiro CHAYA created the dye technique and the design.
The established theory is that it is called 'Chaya' because Shirojiro CHAYA created the dye technique and the design.

sen.j: しかし、茶屋家の本業は呉服屋ではなく、茶屋染の発祥も茶屋家の繁栄した時期とはズレがあるため、この説には疑問もある。
sen.e: However, this theory is also discredited because the chaya family's main business was not kimono shop (draper), and chayazome was not started when the family was prospered.
However, this theory is also discredited because the Chaya family's main business was not a kimono merchant (dry goods store), and chaya-zome was not started when the family prospered.
However, this theory is also discredited because the Chaya family's main business was not a kimono merchant (dry goods store), and chaya-zome was not started when the family prospered.

sen.j: 寛文7年（1667年）に出版された着物図案帳「御ひいなかた」に「ぢしろ 茶やそめ」と書かれた説明が歴史上の初出とされる。
sen.e: The first historical appearance is considered to be the description, "ground color: chayazome" written in the kimono design book "On-hiinakata" published in 1667.
The kimono design book "On-hiinakata" published in 1667, which includes the description "ground color, Chaya-some," is considered to be the first historical appearance.
The kimono design book 'On-hiinakata' published in 1667, which includes the description 'ground color, Chaya-some,' is considered to be the first historical appearance.

sen.j: 主に白（希に薄い黄橙色や浅葱色）の麻地に藍を基本とし黄橙色を併用して模様を書いた着物とされていた。
sen.e: It was regarded as the kimono of white hemp cloth (uncommonly light yellow orange and pale greenish blue) with indigo, the main color, and yellow orange pattern.

The Chayatsuji refers to a kimono such that, generally, on the while (or uncommonly, light yellowish orange or pale greenish blue) hemp cloth, the Chayazome design is done in the basic color of indigo, in combination with yellowish orange.

The Chayatsuji refers to a kimono such that, generally, on the while (or uncommonly, light yellowish orange or pale greenish blue) hemp cloth, the Chayazome design is done in the basic color of indigo, in combination with yellowish orange.

sen.j: この頃は「浸染め」技法であったが、元禄頃に糊防染の技法が発明された。
sen.e: Although "dip dyeing" technique was used in those days, noribosen (to past rice glue on a textile to avoid dyeing) technique was invented in the Genroku era.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In those days a "dip dyeing" technique was used, but craftsmen in the Genroku era invented a noribosen (resist rice paste is applied by stencil to both sides of the fabric to avoid dyeing prior to dip dyeing) technique.

In those days a 'dip dyeing' technique was used, but craftsmen in the Genroku era invented a noribosen (resist rice paste is applied by stencil to both sides of the fabric to avoid dyeing prior to dip dyeing) technique.

sen.j: 繊細な模様を描くことが可能となった。
sen.e: Then it became possible to portray delicate patterns.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: This noribosen enabled kimono designers to portray delicate patterns.
This noribosen enabled kimono designers to portray delicate patterns.

sen.j: この茶屋染の技法が発達して友禅の発明につながったという説もある。
sen.e: There is also a theory that the chayazome technique developed and led to invention of yuzen.
One theory has it that the Chayazome technique developed into the invention of Yuzen.
One theory has it that the Chayazome technique developed into the invention of Yuzen.

sen.j: 皮肉にも友禅の発明により、藍染め主体で地味な茶屋染は流行から外れていった。
sen.e: Ironically, simple chayazome, which was mainly indigo dyeing, went out of fashion because of the invention of yuzen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Ironically, the invention of Yuzen caused the indigo-based, simple Chayazome to go out of fashion.
Ironically, the invention of Yuzen caused the indigo-based, simple Chayazome to go out of fashion.

sen.j: やがて享保の改革など奢侈を戒める風潮が主体となると、町人の関心を失い地味だった茶屋染は武家の婦人に気に入られることとなる。
sen.e: When the tendency to admonish against luxury, such as the Kyoho Reforms, simple chayazome, which had lost merchant and artisan classes' interest, started to please samurai class's ladies.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: After the Kyoho Reforms which were typical of the tendency to admonish against luxury that dominated the order of the day, the simple Chaya-zome had lost the interest of the merchant class but started to please samurai-class ladies.

After the Kyoho Reforms which were typical of the tendency to admonish against luxury that dominated the order of the day, the simple Chaya-zome had lost the interest of the merchant class but started to please samurai-class ladies.

sen.j: 宝永・正徳 (日本)頃には大柄・大胆だった模様が次第に細く小さくなる傾向が現れ始めた。
sen.e: In the Hoei and Shotoku era, the pattern, which used be large and bold, gradually become finer and smaller.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The Hoei and Shotoku eras witnessed a gradual change in the pattern from large and bold to finer and smaller.
The Hoei and Shotoku eras witnessed a gradual change in the pattern from large and bold to finer and smaller.

sen.j: やがて大奥の衣服制度にも正式に取り上げられることとなった。
sen.e: Then it was officially adopted to the dress system of O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants reside).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: The Chayatsuji was officially adopted by the dress system of O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants resided).
The Chayatsuji was officially adopted by the dress system of O-oku (the inner halls of Edo Castle where the wife of the Shogun and her servants resided).

sen.j: 嘉永3年（1850年）「守貞漫稿」（喜多川守貞著）によれば、以下のような内容の記述がされている。
sen.e: "Morisadamanko" (magazines about manners and customs published in the latter period of Edo era) by Morisada KITAGAWA in 1850, describes as following.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: "Morisadamanko" (magazines about manners and customs published in the latter half of the Edo period) by Morisada KITAGAWA in 1850, describes the mode as follows.
sen.cmt: 原文に「i以下･･･」「がされている」と誤植がありましたので修正しました。
sen.e: Morisadamanko' (magazines about manners and customs published in the latter half of the Edo period) by Morisada KITAGAWA in 1850, describes the mode as follows.

sen.j: 「御殿女中の夏服には、辻、茶屋辻、晒布の三種があり、身分の高低によって使い分けられていた」
sen.e: "There are three kinds of summer wear for goten jochu (palace maids), tsuji, chayatsuji and bleached cloth, and they were properly used according to the social position."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: "There are three kinds of summer wear for goten jochu (palace maids) which are Tsuji, Chayatsuji and Sarashinuno (bleached cloth), and they were properly used according to the social position."
There are three kinds of summer wear for goten jochu (palace maids) which are Tsuji, Chayatsuji and Sarashinuno (bleached cloth), and they were properly used according to the social position.'

sen.j: 「茶屋辻は茶屋染によって染められている」
sen.e: "Chayatsuji is dyed by chayazome."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: "Chayatsuji is Chaya-dyed."
Chayatsuji is Chaya-dyed.'

sen.j: 「昔（※17世紀後期～18世紀初）の茶屋染と今（※19世紀前半）の茶屋辻は柄行きが全く異なる。」
sen.e: "The design of old (*from the late 17th century to the early 18th century) chayazome completely differs from the present (*in the early 19th century) chayatsuji.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: "The design of old (i.e. from the late 17th century to the early 18th century) Chayazome completely differs from that of the present (i.e. in the early 19th century)."
sen.cmt: 表現修正。原文文末に閉じ括弧追加。
sen.e: The design of old (i.e. from the late 17th century to the early 18th century) Chayazome completely differs from that of the present (i.e. in the early 19th century).'

sen.j: 「昔の茶屋染は文字や具体的な物を著していたが、今の茶屋辻は（細かい）総模様である」
sen.e: Although old chayazome had letters and specific objects, present Chayatsuji has full (fine) pattern..."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: "The old Chayazome depicted letters and specific objects, whereas the present Chayatsuji has the (fine) full pattern."
sen.cmt: 表現修正。原文文頭に括弧追加。
sen.e: The old Chayazome depicted letters and specific objects, whereas the present Chayatsuji has the (fine) full pattern.'

sen.j: このころに「水辺の風景を表す」という現代の茶屋辻を意味づける特徴も固定化された。
sen.e: At that time the characteristic of present-day chayatsuji, "illustrates the scenery of the waterside" was also fixed.
At that time the "depiction of water scenery" that features the present-day Chayatsuji was also fixed.
At that time the 'depiction of water scenery' that features the present-day Chayatsuji was also fixed.

sen.j: ちなみに「守貞漫稿」にて茶屋辻より格が高いとされた「辻」（「茶屋辻」と区別するため「本辻」とも言われる）とは刺繍や摺匹田（絞り染めを型染めでそれらしく表す染色技法）により色彩も多彩に総柄の模様を表した帷子のことである。
sen.e: By the way, "tsuji" (it may be also called "hontsuji" in order to differentiate from "chayatsuji"), which is considered higher grade than chayatsuji according to "Morisadamanko," refers Katabira, which has various colors and full pattern by embroidery and Surihitta (stenciled imitation of the shibori technique called hitta in which small square motifs with a small dot of color in the center cover a specific area).

Incidentally, "Morisadamanko" ranked "Tsuji" above the Chayatsuji, where the Tsuji (which is also called "Hontsuji" to be distinguished from "Chayatsuji") refers to a Katabira which has a colorful full pattern embroidered and Surihitta-dyed (i.e. a stenciled imitation of a shibori technique called hitta in which small square motifs with a small dot of color in the center cover a specific area).
sen.cmt: 文脈調整。 用語引用： http://www.thekimonogallery.com/glossary.html
sen.e: Incidentally, 'Morisadamanko' ranked 'Tsuji' above the Chayatsuji, where the Tsuji (which is also called 'Hontsuji' to be distinguished from 'Chayatsuji') refers to a Katabira which has a colorful full pattern embroidered and Surihitta-dyed (i.e. a stenciled imitation of a shibori technique called hitta in which small square motifs with a small dot of color in the center cover a specific area).

sen.j: 辻は御台所や御簾中、大名婦人や高位の奥女中にのみ着用が許され、茶屋辻は大奥の中臈未満クラスの着用であった。
sen.e: Only midaidokoro (wife of a shogun or a highest-ranking nobleman), renchu (legal wife of an aristocrat), feudal lord ladies and high-ranking oku-jochu (a maid working in the domestic quarters of a shogun or daimyo) were allowed wear tsuji, and churo (the middle grade ladies-in-waiting) or lower classed women in O-oku wore chayatsuji.

Only the ladies of the highest class at the O-oku, including the Midaidokoro (the shogun's wife), Gorenchu (or Gorenju, the shogun's lawful wives), daimyo's (feudal lords') wives and high-ranking oku-jochu (chambermaids) were allowed to wear the Tsuji, and Churo (the middle-grade ladies-in-waiting) or lower class wore the Chayatsuji.
sen.cmt: 原文「大名婦人」は「大名夫人」に修正しました。Wikiサイト上でも「婦人」とされていますがこれは明らかな誤植と思われます。http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%8C%B6%E5%B1%8B%E8%BE%BB
sen.e: Only the ladies of the highest class at the O-oku, including the Midaidokoro (the shogun's wife), Gorenchu (or Gorenju, the shogun's lawful wives), daimyo's (feudal lords') wives and high-ranking oku-jochu (chambermaids) were allowed to wear the Tsuji, and Churo (the middle-grade ladies-in-waiting) or lower class wore the Chayatsuji.

sen.j: この辻や茶屋辻で多用されたのが、現在「御所解」といわれる文様である。
sen.e: The patterns abundantly used on the tsuji and chayatsuji are now called "goshodoki pattern."
A design that dominated among the Tsuji and Chayatsuji is currently called "Goshodoki."
A design that dominated among the Tsuji and Chayatsuji is currently called 'Goshodoki.'

sen.j: 明治維新によりこれらの制度も崩壊したが、「茶屋辻」のその文様の形式は、一般庶民にも格の高い物として受け入れられた。
sen.e: Although these systems collapsed by the Meiji Restoration, "chayatsuji" pattern is accepted by populace as high-toned formality.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Even after class system collapsed due to the Meiji Restoration, the high-toned formality of the "Chayatsuji" pattern was accepted by populace.
Even after class system collapsed due to the Meiji Restoration, the high-toned formality of the 'Chayatsuji' pattern was accepted by populace.

sen.j: その後、用語の意味は変遷して「茶屋辻」に染められていた模様そのものを指すようになった。
sen.e: Then, the definition changed, and it started to mean pattern itself that was dyed on "chayatsuji."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Thereafter, the definition of the term Chayatsuji changed, and it started to refer to the pattern itself rather than the style of kimono.
Thereafter, the definition of the term Chayatsuji changed, and it started to refer to the pattern itself rather than the style of kimono.

sen.j: 現在も主に夏の訪問着や留袖の模様として、主に絹製品に染められている。
sen.e: At present, it is mainly dyed on silk as the pattern for summer semi-ceremonial kimono and tome-sode kimono.

Still today the Chayatsuji is a popular pattern for summer homon-gi (a kimono worn when visiting someone's home or formal parties) and tomesode (a formal black kimono worn by married women) and is dyed mainly on silk product.
sen.cmt: 文脈調整。 用語引用： http://www.northendkaratedo.com/Website/glossary.htm
sen.e: Still today the Chayatsuji is a popular pattern for summer homon-gi (a kimono worn when visiting someone's home or formal parties) and tomesode (a formal black kimono worn by married women) and is dyed mainly on silk product.
